title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: The story of Fletcher has died away in Angus; but at one time it was inevery mouth, and many a head was shaken as the Sunday loiterers fromDundee and Lochee passed by the Cradle in their walks on Balgay Hill.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: There is nostone to point out the grave of the Indian princess, who lies--asbecomes, too, in our boasted land of liberty, entitled to her boast inan equality at length, which even pride cannot deny--among the humbleartisans and cottars of Lochee.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "Mrs. Geddes, Johnnie Geddes's wife, o' the village o' Lochee, just twamiles frae that sink o' sin, Bonnie Dundee.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: But thedarkness was not of the moon's absence in another hemisphere; only thatdarkness which is cloud-born, and must cede in twinkling yet gloriousintervening moments to the moon, when she will salute the graves and themarriage-guests; and the hearse, as it slowly wended its way up the roadto Lochee, every now and then pouring forth from its dark inside pealsof laughter.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: Yes, Aminadab could not get to the holy of holies except bypassing through Logie kirkyard, a small and most romantic Golgotha, onthe left of the road leading to Lochee, whose inhabitants it contained,and which was so limited and crowded, that one might prefigure it as oneof those holes or dungeons in Michael Angelo's pictures, belching forthspirits in the shape of inverted tadpoles, the tail uppermost, and yetrepresenting ascending sparks.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: The story of Fletcher has died away in Angus ;but at one time it was in every mouth, and manya head was shaken as the Sunday loiterers fromDundee and Lochee passed by the Cradle in theirwalks on Balgay Hill.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: There is no stone to point outthe grave of the Indian princess, who lies—as becomes too in our boasted land of liberty, entitledto her boast in an equality at length, which evenpride cannot deny—among the humble artisansand cottars of Lochee.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: " Mrs Geddes, Johnny Geddes's wife, o' thevillage o' Lochee, just twa miles frae that sink o'sin, Bonnie Dundee.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: How thegreat God can show His power over the little god,man! The woman was no other than a MrsGeddes of Lochee, who, having got a little toomuch at the Scouring Burn, had, on her way home,slipt into the resting-place of her husband, whohad been buried only a week before ; and, havinggot drowsy, had fallen asleep on the flat stonewhich covered him.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: But the darkness wasnot of the moon's absence in another hemisphere;only that darkness which is cloud-born, and mustcede in twinkling yet glorious intervening momentsto the moon, when she will salute the graves andthe marriage-guests; and the hearse, as it slowlywended its way up the road to Lochee, every nowand then pouring forth from its dark inside pealsof laughter.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: Yes, Aminadab could not get to theholy of holies except by passing through LogieKirkyard, a small and most romantic Golgotha onthe left of the road leading to Lochee, whose inhabitants it contained, and which was so limitedand crowded, that one might prefigure it as oneof those holes or dungeons in Michael Angelo'spictures, belching forth spirits in the shape ofinverted tadpoles, the tail uppermost, and yet representing ascending sparks.
